title: Sundays River Formation
text:
The Sundays River Formation is a geological <a href="Geological%20formation">formation</a> found in the <a href="Eastern%20Cape">Eastern</a> and <a href="Western%20Cape">Western Cape</a> provinces in <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a>. It is the second youngest of the four formations found within the <a href="Uitenhage%20Group">Uitenhage Group</a> of the <a href="Algoa%20Basin">Algoa Basin</a>, its type locality, and the only location where outcrops have been located. The Sundays River has been measured at a maximum thickness of .
Geology.
The Sundays River Formation overlies the <a href="Kirkwood%20Formation">Kirkwood Formation</a> which it grades laterally into in certain areas, meaning that they correlate in age in some localities. The <a href="sedimentary%20rock">sedimentary rock</a> of the Sundays River comprises mainly fine to medium grained grey <a href="sandstone">sandstone</a>s which often contain shell fragments, <a href="siltstone">siltstone</a>s, and <a href="mudstone">mudstone</a>s. The sandstone layers are frequently cemented with <a href="calcite">calcite</a> layers. These were deposited in a shallow <a href="Marine%20environment">marine</a> environment which likely included <a href="Estuary">estuarine</a> and <a href="lagoon">lagoon</a>al settings.
Paleontology.
The Sundays River is highly <a href="fossiliferous">fossiliferous</a> and a variety of fossil <a href="flora">flora</a> and <a href="fauna">fauna</a> have been discovered. <a href="Invertebrate">Invertebrate</a> shells from <a href="Ammonoidea">ammonites</a>, <a href="Bivalvia">bivalves</a>, and microfossils such as species of <a href="Foraminifera">forams</a> and <a href="ostracod">ostracod</a>s are commonly found cemented within the <a href="calcite">calcite</a> layers in the sandstone deposits. <a href="Trace%20fossil">Trace fossil</a>s of <a href="Gastropoda">gastropod</a> tracks which are infilled with <a href="siltstone">siltstone</a> are also frequently found. Some <a href="vertebrate">vertebrate</a> fossils have been found, most notably a near-complete skeleton of a marine <a href="Plesiosauria">plesiosaur</a>, "<a href="Leptocleidus">Leptocleidus capensis</a>". However, very little study has been done on the plesiosaur specimen discovered here. Plant remains and non-diagnostic vertebrate fossils have also been recovered.
